abstract.t: This document specifies the "doi" URI scheme for Digital Object Identifier (DOI) names.

section.name: Introduction
section.t: A DOI name is a global unique identifier of a referent, which can be any digital, physical or abstract entity, including inventions, literary and artistic works, ideas, symbols, names, images, designs, etc.

A DOI name is persistent over time. This persistence is provided by the independence of the DOI name from the referent itself and its descriptive elements. These descriptive elements of a referent, including location and ownership, can change over time, and their current values are retrieved by resolving the DOI name. The set of elements retrieved by resolving a DOI name is called the DOI record. The DOI record usually contains a web address (or URL for Unified Resource Locator) representing an instance of the referent, and may contain services such as email, and one or more items of data about the referent (metadata).
This document specifies a URI scheme for DOI names. When resolved, the URI corresponding to a DOI name yields the DOI record associated with the name.
The URI scheme formalizes the notation "doi:<DOI name>", which is in widespread use.

section.name: Syntax
section.t: As specified at , a DOI name consists of an ordered sequence of Unicode code points of the Graphic type.
The scheme-specific-part of the URI corresponding to a given DOI name SHALL be equal to the result of the following ordered sequence of steps:

ol.li: percent-encode any byte in the UTF-8 String that is neither unreserved nor equal to "/".

section.t: The URI shall contain neither a query component nor a fragment component.

aside.t: EXAMPLE 1: The DOI name "10.5594/SMPTE.ST2067-21.2020" corresponds to the URI <doi:10.5594/SMPTE.ST2067-21.2020.
EXAMPLE 2: The DOI name "10.26321/Á.GUTIÉRREZ.ZARZA.02.2018.03" corresponds to the URI <doi:10.26321/%C3%81.GUTI%C3%89RREZ.ZARZA.02.2018.03>.

NOTE 1: The sequence of code points comprising a DOI name is not normalized: two DOI names that differ only in one having the code point sequence <U+00C1> replaced by <U+0041, U+0301> in other are not identical even though they are both code point sequences are rendered identically as the abstract character "Á" .

NOTE 2: Presenting a DOI name by rendering its sequence of code points to glyphs can be ambiguous since multiple code points or sequences of code points can result in the same glyphs. For example, U+002D HYPHEN-MINUS, U+2212 MINUS SIGN and U+2013 EN DASH are rendered as similar glyphs. As another example, the abstract character "á" can be represented by either the code point U+00E1 or the sequence of code points <U+0061, U+0301>. Presenting a DOI name in its URI form resolves this ambiguity.
